column4: hey guys, does "glibc2" go by any other package name?  I'm trying to install it without compiling from source
why do you want it?
I'm trying to install LabVIEW, and it requires it
are you compiling labview?
no, but the first thing I see after I run the install file says "WARNING!  You do not have glibc2 (libc.so.6) installed.
is it a 32bit app perhaps?
I'm not positive, but being a very scientific app I highly doubt it
check?
checking
damn, looks like it is a 32 bit program.
good call
try installing libc6:i386 using apt-get
mcphail, thanks for the tip.  grabbing them as we speak.  I suppose that since it is a 32 bit program, I need the 32 bit c std library for it to work with?
mcphail, i grabbed libc6-i386 and libc6-i386-dev, but it's still griping about libc.so.6 (glibc2)
not sure that's the same.  use the :
i think it is, but I'll fire up synaptic and check it out
you're right, there are two different packages.  Any idea on the difference?
no
then there is this monster: libc6-dev-amd64:i386
nice
I guess that's for compiling for other arches than your current one
I have libc6:i386 installed, the description for the other is "Contains the symlinks and object files needed to compile and link programs
